candidates.title: Did a KGB Agent Confirm That the Sex Pistols Were Backed by the USSR to Destabilize the West?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A KGB agent admitted that the Sex Pistols were financed by the USSR to destabilize Western democracy.
Rating:
False
About this rating
On 9 May 2017, Facebook page "The Church of PUNK" shared an article reporting that a KGB agent admitted the band the Sex Pistols were an operation backed by the former Soviet Union to destabilize Western democracy:
The April 2015 article reported that at the time it was published, a former KGB agent had just disclosed the punk rock plot:
Alexandrei Varennikovic Voloshin, a retired KGB agent, has admitted this week on National Russian Television (NTV) that the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) was behind the creation of the 1970s punk scene and financed major punk bands such as the Sex Pistols, the Clash and the Ramones.
The USSR government at the time spent hundreds of millions of rubles on this covert operation destined to create utter chaos and pervert the Western youth to nihilist, anti-establishment and anti-american ideologies he explained in an hour long interview broadcast on national television.
There is no truth to this story; World News Daily Report states on its own disclaimer page that all of the content on the site is fictional:
WNDR assumes however all responsibility for the satirical nature of its articles and for the fictional nature of their content. All characters appearing in the articles in this website  even those based on real people  are entirely fictional and any resemblance between them and any persons, living, dead, or undead is purely a miracle.
candidates.description: A Facebook page for punk fans recirculated an old (and fake) story that the Sex Pistols were a KGB plot to foment dissent in the West.

result.explanation: The claim in the news caption is explicitly labeled as "False" by Snopes, a reputable fact-checking website.  Snopes cites a satirical article from World News Daily Report as the origin of the claim, which states that all its content is fictional. The evidence directly contradicts the news caption.
result.supporting_points: Source 1: Snopes fact-check explicitly labels the claim as false.  Source 1 states that the claim originated from a satirical article that explicitly states all its content is fictional.

final_result.explanation: The image shows a singer performing on stage. The caption claims that a KGB agent admitted the Sex Pistols were financed by the USSR to destabilize Western democracy.  There is no visual evidence in the image to support this claim. The image contains no indication of the Sex Pistols, the USSR, KGB agents, or any political themes related to Western democracy. Internal validation finds the caption unrelated to the image content (confidence_score 0). External validation strongly refutes the claim, citing Snopes' fact-check which labels it as false and attributes the origin to a satirical source (confidence_score 10).  The complete mismatch between the image and the caption, along with strong external evidence confirming the falsity of the caption's claim, leads to a high confidence level that the caption is out of context. There's no ambiguity; the image and claim are wholly unrelated. No visual tampering or miscontextualization is detected.  The external evidence definitively overrides the internal assessment, leading to a final confidence score of 10. The internal check's low confidence score reflects the lack of connection between the visual data and the text.  The external check's high confidence score stems from the reliable source directly contradicting the claim. In summary, both internal and external analysis confirm that the caption bears no relation to the image and thus is completely out of context.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external validation confirm that the caption is out of context. The image depicts a singer, unrelated to the caption's claim about KGB financing of the Sex Pistols and its impact on Western democracy.  External fact-checking definitively refutes the caption's assertion.
